channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Video Appears to Show Decapitated Body of a Japanese Hostage of ISIS
item.description: The Japanese government expressed outrage at an image released Saturday that appeared to show the decapitated body of one of two Japanese hostages captured by Islamic State militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Islamic State group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Haruna Yukawa, right, in an image released by the Islamic State on Jan. 20, was said on Saturday to have been killed. The other hostage, Kenji Goto, appeared to still be alive.

item.title: Belgium Confronts the Jihadist Danger Within
item.description: The thwarted terrorist operation highlighted the dangers posed by a well-developed underground pipeline that has made Belgium the biggest per capita contributor in Europe of fighters to Syria.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Molenbeek district in Brussels, where a jihadist pipeline has made Belgium Europe’s biggest per capita contributor of fighters to Syria.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Crusading for Israel in a Way Some Say Is Misguided
item.description: To show, as she put it, “there is a price to Jewish blood,” Nitsana Darshan-Leitner sues nations, terrorist organizations and others that have harmed Israelis — angering some on the left in Israel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: “I understood that I can come on behalf of terror victims, give them a voice, and get my day in a court. It doesn’t matter what the decision is," says Nitsana Darshan-Leitner.

item.title: Japan Vows to Continue Effort to Win Hostages’ Release
item.description: Militants had not offered a clear signal of their intentions even after Japan appeared to let the Friday deadline pass without paying the demanded $200 million.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: North Korea’s Forbidden Love? Smuggled, Illegal Soap Operas
item.description: Despite a crackdown on smugglers, South Korean soap operas are sneaking visions of a comfortable lifestyle into North Korea, causing some to defect.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Filming of “Quiz From God,” a South Korean drama, at a studio near Paju.

item.title: Libyan Militant Group Says Its Leader, Mohammed al-Zahawi, Was Killed
item.description: Ansar al-Shariah gave no details, after months of rumors that Mr. Zahawi had been wounded or killed in an attack.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Snubbed by U.S. and Europe, Kremlin Looks to Asia at Davos
item.description: Russian businessmen said privately that their meetings this year were almost exclusively with Chinese, Indian and Middle East partners or potential investors.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Egyptian Court Orders Retrial for Dozens of Muslim Brotherhood Members
item.description: The court ordered a retrial for 37 Muslim Brotherhood members sentenced to death and 115 others sentenced to life in a mass trial last year.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Open Source: Woman Is Killed as Egypt Police Halt Marchers Carrying Flowers to Tahrir Square
item.description: Graphic images of a young woman being fatally wounded as peaceful protesters carrying flowers marched in Cairo infuriated Egyptian activists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Graphic images of Shaimaa al-Sabbagh, an Egyptian activist who was shot and killed at a peaceful rally in Cairo on Saturday, sowed outrage on social networks.

item.title: After Long Legal Fight, Inquest Is Set to Begin in Death of Putin Critic
item.description: Hearings will start this week in London on the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer in self-exile, who accused President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia of ordering his murder.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander Litvinenko, outside the High Court in London last July.

item.title: Despite a Crackdown, Use of Illegal Drugs in China Continues Unabated
item.description: For all the reported successes of China’s constantly expanding antidrug campaigns, the police appear to be winning few significant victories in what the authorities have called a “people’s war.”
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: A drug seizure in Guangdong Province.

item.title: Human Rights Groups Press Obama on India
item.description: As President Obama visits India to improve the strained relationship between the two countries, some human rights groups hope their concerns are not swept under the rug.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: The arrest of Devyani Khobragade, center, was a factor in the recent strained relations between India and the United States.

item.title: For Auschwitz Museum, a Time of Great Change
item.description: As the Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum observes the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration camps, it is focusing on new generations of visitors.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Auschwitz, center of Nazi atrocities. The museum will shift its emphasis, explaining the horrors to new generations of visitors.

item.title: Experts See Signs of Moderation Despite Houthis’ Harsh Slogans
item.description: Experts and analysts say it would be premature to dismiss the Houthis as Yemen’s Hezbollah, despite their alliance with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Yemenis confronted a member of the Houthis during an anti-Houthi demonstration in Sana, Yemen, on Saturday.

item.title: Japan Seeks to Verify Video of Hostage Death
item.description: An unconfirmed image released Saturday purported to show the decapitated body of one of two Japanese hostages captured by Islamic State militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Rifts Between U.S. and Nigeria Impeding Fight Against Boko Haram
item.description: The militants are charging through northern Nigeria, razing villages, abducting children and forcing tens of thousands of people to flee.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Soldiers from the Chadian Army at the border between Nigeria and Cameroon, part of a regional force that has been fighting Boko Haram militants.

item.title: Police Arrest 4 in North Africa Amid Fears of Attack in Spain
item.description: Spain’s Interior Ministry said the police in its North African enclave arrested four men suspected of belonging to a militant Islamist network that may have been planning an attack.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 27 Are Killed by Rockets in Ukraine
item.description: Rockets struck homes and a market in the Azov Sea port city of Mariupol on Saturday, the latest indication that the war has flared up again in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Residents in Mariupol, Ukraine, near the covered body of a man who was killed during shelling on Saturday.

item.title: Meant to Keep Malaria Out, Mosquito Nets Are Used to Haul Fish In
item.description: The nets, with holes smaller than mosquitoes, trap much more than traditional fishing nets do and could wipe out stressed fish populations in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Obama Will End India Trip Early to Visit Saudi Arabia
item.description: The president will cancel a tour of the Taj Mahal and instead fly to Saudi Arabia, where he will meet with the late King Abdullah’s successor, White House officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
